newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-MATT WILLIAMS SINGLES IN WINNING RUN IN 10TH.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-MATT WILLIAMS SINGLES IN WINNING RUN IN 10TH.

text.p: Matt Williams had an apparent
homer taken away in the sixth inning but had the last laugh
when he blooped home the winning run in the bottom of the 10th
to give the Cleveland Indians their third straight victory,
5-4 over the Toronto Blue Jays Friday.
The Indians, who blew a two-run ninth-inning lead, rallied
in the 10th against Tim Crabtree (2-3). Omar Vizquel led off
with a hustling bloop double and took third on a grounder.
"I saw the ball hit on the line and I said to myself,
Don't stop, don't even stop, give it a shot and see if I could
get to second base," Vizquel said.
Jim Thome and David Justice were intentionally walked to
load the bases and the Jays brought in their infield before
Williams sent an 0-2 pitch into short left to score Vizquel.
"I just wanted to get it in the air and over the infield,"
said Williams. "I swung through the first pitch and he gave me
a good one to hit on the second one, but I hit a foul ball.
The hit was just a wedge shot."
In the sixth, Williams hit a liner down the left-field
line that was called a two-run homer by third-base umpire Dave
Phillips. Toronto manager Cito Gaston argued with plate umpire
Durwood Merrill, who conferred with Phillips and ruled a foul
ball. Cleveland manager Mike Hargrove argued and was ejected.
"I didn't see it," Williams said. "When I hit first base,
I saw the umpire signal fair ball. When Cito came out of the
dugout, I knew something was amiss. The longer that went on, I
pretty much figured it was foul."
"It was a good call by Durwood Merrill," Gaston said. "It
was the right thing for Phillips to do, to go down and ask
Merrill and get the call right."
Paul Assenmacher (4-0) allowed one hit in the 10th but got
the win. Jose Mesa lost a 4-2 lead in the ninth, his fourth
blown save in nine chances.
Thome, Jeff Branson and Brian Giles homered for Cleveland.
In Baltimore, the Orioles and Mariners split a
doubleheader, Seattle losing with ace Randy Johnson pitching
but then winning with a rookie.
Johnson (16-4) allowed homers by Jeff Reboulet and Jeffrey
Hammonds to lose the opener 4-3. Scott Kamieniecki (8-5)
allowed one run in seven innings as he won for just the second
time in his last eight starts.
Coming off a five-hitter with 19 strikeouts against the
White Sox, Johnson pitched a four-hitter for his fifth
complete game and struck out 13 against three walks. Johnson
is 1-5 lifetime in Baltimore.
Johnson tied the major-league mark for strikeouts in
consecutive games, set by Cleveland's Luis Tiant in 1968 and
matched by California'a Nolan Ryan in 1974 and the Mets'
Dwight Gooden in 1984.
In the nightcap, Baltimore native Ken Cloude allowed two
hits over six innings in his second major-league start and Ken
Griffey Jr, Jay Buhner and Alex Rodriguez homered as the
Mariners beat the Orioles 8-3.
Cloude (1-1), a 22-year-old right-hander who flirted with
a no-hitter before losing his major-league debut last week,
gave up two runs, striking out two and walking six.
In New York, Dwight Gooden pitched six solid innings and
Bernie Williams broke out of a slump with two hits and two RBI
as the Yankees rolled to a 5-2 victory over the Texas Rangers,
who had their four-game winning streak snapped.
Gooden (6-4) rebounded from his worst outing of the season
to win for the third time in four decisions. He gave up two
runs and four hits.
The Yankees have won three straight, six of their last
seven and 14 of 18 to move within 3 1/2 games of first-place
Baltimore in the American League East.
In Milwaukee, Chuck Finley allowed three runs over seven
innings to tie a franchise record with his 10th straight
victory as the Anaheim Angels moved back into first place in
the A.L. West with a 5-3 victory over the Brewers.
Finley (13-6) scattered eight singles.
Newly acquired Rickey Henderson had a single, three walks,
a stolen base and two runs scored for Anaheim, which moved
one-half game ahead of Seattle.
In Boston, Reggie Jefferson singled home pinch-runner Mike
Benjamin in the bottom of the 10th as the Red Sox dealt the
Minnesota Twins their seventh straight loss, 5-4.
Jim Corsi squandered a two-run lead in the top of the
ninth as the Boston bullpen suffered its 19th blown save in 47
chances.
But Mo Vaughn led off the bottom half with a double off
the "Green Monster" in left field to revive Boston hopes.
Jefferson, just 9-for-44 against left-handers this season,
fouled off two pitches from southpaw Eddie Guardado (0-4)
before singling to center for the game-winner.
In Chicago, Jimmy Haynes allowed four runs over five
innings but benefited from Matt Stairs' three-run homer and a
14-hit attack as the Oakland Athletics cruised to their third
straight win, 11-6 over the White Sox.
In Detroit, Bip Roberts had a two-run single as the Kansas
City Royals scored four unearned runs in the second en route
to a 5-3 victory over the Tigers.
